text:
Amber’s mother suggested that Amber could use the ideas of “in the black” or “in the red” to model addition and subtraction of integers using red and black chips. Amber’s mother gives the following example.

  • Tate owes his sister $6 for helping him cut the lawn. He earns $4 watering a neighbor’s plants.

Amber uses the board to the left to claim that Tate is “in the red” 2 dollars or has –2 dollars.

She writes +4 + –6 = –2
• Why do you think she concludes that +4 + –6 = –2?
Possible answer: If you lose 6 dollars and you only gain 4 dollars back, then your total change will be a loss of 2 dollars. This is modeled in the number sentence -6 + 4 = -2.
• What is another way to show a total value of –2 on the chip board?

Many possible answers: You could have:

  • two red chips on the board with no black chips,
  • 1 black chip and 3 red chips,
  • 2 black chips and 4 red chips,
  • 3 black chips and 5 red chips, etc.

Any value of black chips could work, as long as you have 2 extra red chips.
• Suppose she changes the board by adding one red chip and one black chip. How much does this change the total value?
It does not change the total value at all. Adding 1 black chip and 1 red chip represents adding 1 + -1, which equals zero.
